awd_abstract_narration:
Recent decades have witnessed an extraordinary growth in cyber-physical systems (CPS) such as self-driving vehicles, robotic devices, and drones. The First EAI SmartSP2023 conference, an independent conference, provides a valuable venue for the cyber-physical systems (CPS) research, with a particular focus on smart vehicles, smart transportation, and corresponding security challenges. The conference brings together leading experts worldwide to share knowledge, explore emerging trends and technologies, and address the many challenges associated with these technologies. The conference is particularly relevant for students and early-career researchers seeking to expand their knowledge, develop essential career skills, and engage in discussions with leading experts in the field. Attendees will have the opportunity to attend technical sessions, present their research, and participate in panel discussions and networking events. The conference will also provide opportunities for students to meet with leading experts in the field, explore potential career opportunities, and gain valuable insights into the latest research and emerging technologies in CPS and smart vehicles.

The conference grant helps cover travel expenses for student attendees. The selection will be based on a range of criteria, including academic achievement and research experience and will give priority to students who have demonstrated a commitment to advancing the field. Assessment of learning outcome for student attendees will be conducted through a range of methods, including pre- and post-conference surveys, feedback from student presentations, and evaluations of student engagement in technical sessions and discussions. The conference organizers will work with participating universities and research institutions to ensure that students receive credit for attending the conference and that their participation is recognized as part of their academic and professional development.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Computer and Information Science and Engineering
org_div_long_name: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

por.por_cntn:
This NSF-funded project supported eight diverse students from various racial, gender, and geographic backgrounds across the United States to travel to Chicago, IL, to attend the EAI SMARTSP2023 conference. This initiative was designed to provide these students with hands-on exposure to cutting-edge research in cyber-physical systems (CPS), smart vehicles, and associated security challenges. Through this project, we aimed to cultivate the students' research skills, foster professional networking opportunities, and inspire future contributions to the field.

Intellectual Merit:

The project successfully enhanced the intellectual development of participating students by immersing them in a highly specialized research environment. At the conference, the students attended keynote presentations, technical sessions, and panel discussions led by experts in CPS and related areas. Topics covered included recent advancements in CPS, innovative approaches to smart vehicle development, and pressing security issues associated with these technologies. Exposure to these discussions allowed the students to deepen their understanding of both foundational and emerging topics in CPS research.

Additionally, students had the opportunity to present their own work and receive constructive feedback from senior researchers and industry professionals. This experience helped them refine their research methodologies and enhanced their communication and presentation skills. The students left the conference better equipped to conduct high-quality research, having gained insights from leading experts and received valuable input on their projects.

Broader Impacts:

This project had a profound impact on promoting diversity and inclusion within the STEM field, particularly in CPS research. The group of eight students represented a broad spectrum of identities, including diverse races, gender identities, and geographic locations within the U.S. This diversity not only enriched the students' own experiences but also promoted a more inclusive environment at the conference by bringing varied perspectives to the discussions.

Moreover, the project contributed to building a stronger research community by creating networking opportunities for these students with professionals and academics in the field. Many of the students established valuable connections with researchers and potential mentors, laying the groundwork for future collaborations and career opportunities. By supporting students from underrepresented backgrounds, the project took a meaningful step towards reducing barriers in accessing high-level research experiences and fostering an inclusive pipeline in CPS research.

Outcomes and Impact Summary:

Through this NSF-funded travel grant, the students were able to gain invaluable research experience, deepen their understanding of CPS and smart vehicle technology, and connect with experts in the field. Many students expressed newfound inspiration and confidence in pursuing advanced research, with some planning to continue their work in CPS and cybersecurity. Feedback from the students highlighted that this conference was a transformative experience, providing them with a clearer vision of their future careers and instilling a commitment to contribute to the CPS field.

Overall, this project successfully achieved its objectives by broadening the students' perspectives, enhancing their research skills, and fostering a sense of community and belonging within STEM. The project outcomes underscore the importance of such initiatives in empowering the next generation of researchers, especially those from diverse and underrepresented backgrounds, to engage meaningfully in impactful scientific work.

 


Last Modified: 11/09/2024
Modified by: Kaichen Yang
